entry.title: Learning to drive in Ontario? Beware of Contradictions
entry.summary:
The process of learning to drive in an incredibly stressful one. From reading about all sorts of hieroglyphic - looking symbols you've never seen before, to being at the mercy of any one of the many questionable driver trainers out there (I could probably be counted among them even though I have good intentions). At some point, the process of learning this massive undertaking may seem impossible, but it's not. Trust me on that. What you can't trust is much of what you read either.

A simple disclosure - I have been driving now for almost 21 years. I've seen a great many things which I won't elaborate about here. What I have also seen, is many friends and family going though the process of learning to drive. One such unbelievable example is while working with my sister Crystal as she was answering yet another confusing question. This one related to how many demerit points are lost when you reverse in a car without a seatbelt. Do you know the answer to that one?
Can you trust your Official MTO Driver Handbook to answer that question? Let's see, I'm going to take the current version of this handbook and show you.
First, Page 29 - Regarding Seat Belts
[![image][]][image]
Take a look at the above picture of page 29 of the handbook. It says "Use your seatbelt always, even when you are sitting in a position with an active airbag". Certainly seat belts are an important safety feature of a car, and it would be reasonable to think you should be wearing them "always". As a young driver learning this, you've read up to page 29 of the "Official" Ministry of Transportation Handbook, so - more that being proud of yourself - you assume this must be right. Right?
Now, I don't want to quibble with word meanings too much, but "always" tends to mean all the time, or perhaps EVERY time. It's safe to say that "always" would be a more definitive way of communicating "if your butt is in the seat and the vehicle is moving, wear a seat belt".
Next, go to Page 55 - Regarding Reversing
[![image][1]][1]
The above is a picture of page 55 of the same handbook. It clearly states "You don't have to wear a seat belt while backing up". This is a clear and direct contradiction of previously stated "Use your seat belt always". What is a person who might just be trying to figure out the rules of the road do? Which is right? Why the intentional contradiction in the first place?
The law does say this - in the Highway Traffic Act, the following exemptions apply:
106.(5)Exemptions

You don’t have to wear a seat belt if:

\1) You’re driving in reverse

So, one of these two points in the Handbook is correct. Let's hope they work to make this handbook clearer for the learners. We need better drivers on the road, not more laws!

entry.title: Let the home buyer beware: When water heaters aren't cool
entry.summary:
[![image][]][image]

I'm a new home owner, and as such, not an expert in real estate. With all the things that happen when one buys a house, you'd be hard pressed to understand every nuanced part of every deal. Today while looking at some paperwork, I discovered how the previous homeowners pulled something of a trick on me and how I should have been more diligent about the process. Hopefully after seeing this, you'll be more watchful of your own home buying process.

I do have egg on my face over this - but more than looking like a fool - I wanted to share how others might avoid this sort of pain and frustration in the future.

Today, a fellow from National Home Services came to the house trying to sell (for the hundredth time) a new water heater. He was fairly rude and I tried to be as courteous as I could. It appears there is no way to stop these people from coming to your door. I had heard about National Home Services, but did not really know much more than the fact that I see them on my Enbridge bill. Since I had never signed a contract with them, I would not be subject to the horror stories others mention. But, I had always wondered why they are charging me for a water heater.

What I see on my bill every month

So, today I took the step of calling them and asking what the nature of my business with them was. The woman on the other end first asked for my address and I gave it to her. Then she asked for my home sales agreement - this was a little too much information to give out - so I refused this request. She seemed quite perturbed by my refusal to provide information. But, she was willing to assist and offered to send me the current agreement they had that was in a previous owner's name. That agreement was signed by the previous owner on July 15th, 2008. I took over the house somewhere around August or September of 2008, so this happened JUST before I moved in. The woman from National tells me this contract is a 15 year contract and to get out of it, I would have to pay a $575.00 cancellation fee.

Hey, that's not me

Now, the reason why the woman at National Home Services wanted to see my agreement was because of one simple line that would either stick me for the contract or allow me to get out of it. This is item #6 of a typical contract that determines what stuff the new owner takes on. In my case it says "Hot Water Tank".

[![image][3]][3]

Are you seeing this? Some of the more astute of you might be able to see past my boneheadedness and see what's going on here. The previous owner, in a pinch decided that the house sale would look much better with a SHINY NEW hot water heater decided to sign a 15 year contract with National Home Services just before selling and then slyly include that in the sales agreement passing it off to me. As a first time, inexperienced home buyer, I didn't think to look for that, nor did I figure it out until some time later.

How does this translate to money, you ask?

For the life of this contract to National Home Services, I will have paid $2,251.80(or more considering increases). To continue and finish the contract from today, I will need to pay $1,651.32 (or more) for the rest of the term. To get out of the contract right now, the minimum charge (cancellation fee) is $575.00. Since National Home Services doesn't even see me as a customer - I also get sales calls!

Comparable water heater $553.00 + possibly $250.00 installation: $803.00 + Taxes.

Boy, do I feel stupid.

Update: After waiting close to a month for a response about a water heater buyout - National Home Services responded with this message on March 14th:

[![image][4]][4]

$1,039.40 is steep, but it appears the best option I have for the lifetime of the heater. This will (at least) save me $611.92 or more for the lifetime of the water heater. This also gives me the option of a direct replacement down the road (if I choose to go after a more efficient model). Perhaps most important, I don't have to saddle the next home owner with a ludicrous contract if the house is sold.

entry.title: It's time to vote for REAL change. This October I vote Libertarian.
entry.summary:
[![image][]][image]

Firstly, I want to make it clear, no matter what I say - my hope is that you choose to do what is so important to our way of life. Please vote in this coming Ontario Provincial Election on October 6th, 2011 (click here to find your electoral district) and make your voice heard.

Thank you, now it's time to talk about how I'll vote. In the past Ontario elections I have voted Green party and if I were to go back further, Liberal. This year none of those will get my vote.

This year I vote Liberation.

Liberation? What's that, you say? Is that something to do with the Liberals? No.

The Liber- in Liberation comes from Liberty, not Liberal.

Liberty is:

The state of being free within society from oppressive restrictions imposed by authority on one's way of life, behavior, or political views

For me, the essence of this is that you know what's best for you your family. No other authority can tell you what's best for you. I can't tell you what's best for you.

I really don't know why this isn't more popular. Just a couple days ago, the candidate for the Oshawa Liberation party in Oshawa, Matthew Belanger, was nice enough to meet with me - and I asked him that very question.

"We're just not out there. It's hard to get the word out"

I'll say.

It's more than hard when you're considered what he calls a "fringe" party. You likely won't see the Libertarians in any sort of provincial debate or media platform. Last night's debate only included three parties. What they're talking about is a massive, no, MONSTER shift in policies from where we are now.

Can you imagine completely privatized medicine? Privatized Education?

Can you imagine all roads privatized?

Can you imagine the end of welfare?

Can you imagine the buying and selling beer and wine anywhere?

Can you imagine taxes being a mere fraction of what they are now?

What the Liberation party wants is for the Government to get the hell outof our lives (with the exception of a few things) and let us live the way we see fit. They want to let us keep our money to do what we think is best for ourselves, our family. Imagine a day when you start by getting paid double what you have now (after all, tax freedom day is in june). What would you do with it?

I feel it's time to make huge changes. The oppressively taxed, over bureaucratic system we're a part of today is NOT working. We're part of a culture of too much Government and too much entitlement.

UPDATE - October 11th, 2011 - As it turns out - I live in the WHITBY-OSHAWA riding and there was no Libertarian on the ballot. I was forced to vote another party and vote for what I thought was best. I felt, this time around, that we had very little time to prepare for this vote. The voter turnout was extremely low - Christine Elliott of the PC party was the winner.

entry.title: Can you "do nothing"?
entry.summary:
image

Today I found a wonderful and fascinating post on the Sociological Images blog about the idea of doing nothing. That's right - just standing motionless, with no facial expression, doing absolutely nothing at all. The idea of taking 262 students, placing them in a public place and have them just stand around like this (see video) seemed like a very interesting idea. What are our reactions to seeing others break society's norms and how do we feel as we're breaking them? How does our norm of constantly being busy effect us as a society?

The experiment I mentioned was conducted at Georgia Southern University by a lecturer named Nathan Palmer (see his post). This happened locally at the campus and, from what it seems in the video, the students were confined to a fairly small space. Take a look at this short video:

What is doing nothing anyway? Try this: Go sit down on a chair or couch and not pick up your phone, read anything, watch anything, or talk to anyone. Try and sit, motionless, making no facial expressions, not talking to anyone. You'll find that this is not only weird, this is actually extremely difficult. Shortly you'll think of something to do or your phone will ring or someone will call you. In our North American society, one of the most pervasive social norms is our need to stay busy all the time.

And even acting busy works. I worked at Burger King for upwards of 8 years and one of the things we were told to do when tending to a customer is to look busy. Yes, there are times when we would have nothing but waiting for something to cook, but you could go and grab a bag, go badger someone about how quickly they're making a sandwich or generally just walk back and forth erratically. This tends to work for people, because, while they wait for something, watching a person "act" busy makes them feel like something will get done faster.

Look at the example of an elevator button. Many of us will go up to an elevator and press the button and stand there fixed in a stare on the small screen that tells us where the elevator is. But, there are allot of folks that will also continued to press that button with some sort of intention that pressing the button repeatedly will make the elevator move faster? Perhaps we do it just for something to do?

The whole idea of it being unacceptable in our society to do nothing is underscored by our collective difficulty in maintaining a sense of calm. I see many people everyday that can't seem to handle silence or have any sense of patience (increasingly, this includes myself). When they have to wait for an appointment, people need to have reading materials close to them. When we wait in a line, we need to be using our smart phones looking for updates of some sort. It seems as if our social norm of being busy all the time my be starting to effect our health. I wonder if there have been studies about this kind of thing? It wouldn't be too much of a stretch to think that our need to be busy may correlate to North America's decline in mental health.

Despite the kind of blockbuster news it would be to find out that all we need for better mental health is just slow down or stop sometimes; You probably don't need to go far to see examples of moments when you could have taken advantage of stopping and didn't do it. One of the biggest examples of this for me was when I spent two weeks backpacking in Panama a few years ago. The trip took me to the San Blas Islands, a beautiful set of islands in the north of Panama. The island we were staying at housed a few travellers and one family that did the cooking for us. The rest fo the trip involved no more than eating food, taking the 5 minute walk from edge to edge of the island and sleeping in your hammock. Rather quickly, the power on all of my electronic devices ran out and I had no actual books to read. This would have been the perfect moment to embrace doing nothing, but I tended to want to leave as soon as possible.

Isla Robinson - one of the San Blas islands that I visited in 2008

As time passess, we all might benefit from using some of it to just sit down, turn everything off and do nothing. Perhaps if more of us even did nothing in public or while waiting for things, it would be less of an unusual thing for people to do? Even more valuable for those of us that don't meditate, the act of doing nothing may lead you closer to understanding and even practicing meditation. Maybe not, but it would make you one hell of a better driving companion on those long trips.

entry.title: The New, New Dominican in January 2011 - Part 2
entry.summary:
In my last post on the Dominican, I offered an explanation of that special "thing" that gets me back there time and time again. That thing is what as made me (some years) go back up to 4 times in a 12 month period. That's more often than I've been to Vancouver, for those counting. In this, the second part of the series, I'd like to share some stories and anecdotes from this recent trip.

So, on this trip I had some clear ideas about what I was going to do differently (from other recent trips to the Dominican). One change I was going to make was to take more pictures and video. I think you'll see in the next post, that I did succeed in that respect. The sheer volume of pictures and video I captured was staggering. Another plan I had before leaving, was to integrate more into the local lifestyle more than I ever have. To that end, let me explain how some these efforts unfolded.


Getting local voice and data service (prepaid) was one very important plan I had. I spent some time online looking up the different phone companies (Orange, Claro, Vivo) and their frequencies used and network coverage. Since I'm using am HTC G2 - it was clear that Orange was the network I would need to use. The process itself will be covered in another post, but I wanted to share some of the fun that I encountered while trying to get what I needed. The first step was getting voice access at a mall.

When I had arrived at the mall and found the Orange Shop - the man at the counter seemed to speak English great. He was personal able and seemed also to know exactly what I needed. Then, he said "I need your passport". My jaw dropped and I said I didn't have it. He then says he needed a passport to setup and account. Bizarre. This then began a process of me running between the resort, the mall, and another small range kiosk in a Super Mercado.

This little booth was closer to the resort, so it made sense not to go all the way back to the mall - but when I got there it was busy. The counter was filled with people, so I just stood behind the person who seemed to look like he'd be the first to go. Not much was happening when a person came up to the counter, said something in Spanish (that I didn't understand), paid and left. I was a little taken aback here until I realized that the concept of waiting in lines is kind of a foreign one to many Dominicans. I immediately asserted myself up to the counter and asked in English for "prepaid voice".

Wow, that didn't go so good. I got a blank look from that. I sure wish I had taken a picture of his face. The next thing I attempted was to show my phone and say "prepago". Well, this was enough for the fellow who seemed to be squatting at the booth to my right to start speaking in Spanish and then to me in English and he helped me communicate what I was after to the person working in the small booth. That worked out, despite him telling me about 18 times that my phone was still "locked". That would be one of the many times on this trip I would wish for fluent command of Spanish.

My next experience with phone service was while waiting for a bus at the terminal in Santo Domingo. I had about an hour free and there was another Orange both just sitting in front of my (while I drink my bottle of water). Since I didn't have data access an I had recently found out how to hook this up, I decided I would give this a shot. I spoke to the lady and said that I wanted "Prepaid data on a USB stick". I pointed at a picture of it and we were off to the races. One passport and about $30 later, I was set to go. At some point she was trying to explain to me in Spanish that this access to the Internet was only good for "ono dia". Ok, 24 hours, that's cool. But, how much data am I able to use? That question didn't work out so well. What happened next (after seeing she had a computer) was a comical exchange using the Google Translate website to translate text back and forth. Since Google didn't really get the essence of what I was asking it took a few attempts to figure out the best way to ask my question. Eventually, thanks to Google, I found out that I would be allotted 1 GB of data for the day while in use.

The process of bussing from Punta Cana to Puerto Plata was another somewhat comical process. The cabbie I had met in Punta Cana was great and dropped me at the express bus to Santo Domingo, which was perfect. Once we stopped in Santo Domingo at a fairly nondescript corner in the city, I wasn't aware of this being where I would have to get off. The bus driver came up to me and was screaming allot of Spanish words but among them were the "Terminal". He was saying I had to get off. Since my bag was already out, he directed me to another man who I thought was going to show me where the Terminal was (I looked around and it was nowhere to be seen). He went up to a person, grabbed keys and took me to a car. I hopped in and we were off. I thought "Am I in a cab?" "Am I going to have to pay for this trip?". After a few blocks, I saw the large Grand Caribe terminal to the right. The man driving the car helped me with my bags and let me go and I had nothing to pay.

After getting to Puerto Plata, my good friend Yanelis was at the bus top waiting for me. We then went over to her house (via motorcycle) and I visited everyone until Davi came by. With Davi, we went up to his house in the mountain and I stayed there for a couple nights. What a wonderful, refreshing experience. Despite being bitten by mosquitoes like crazy (I didn't realize that's what the net was for), I was loving it.

When I woke up in the morning, this is what I saw. Just incredible:

A few days later, my travel companion Julio decided he wanted to rent a car for 24 hours. The rental was going to cost $70 US cash (with insurance). The great thing about this is that Julio wanted me to drive. You may not be familiar with the driving differences from Canada, but many of the rules are different. I find it to be more of a pleasurable experience to drive there because of how things are more organic on the road. That was a fun day.

I'm told (by someone who speaks the language) that I have about 20% command of speaking Spanish and about 40% recognition of the spoken language. I have the sense that total immersion in a location with the language is really the on way I'm going to take myself to the next level and get to being fluent to a level of 40-50%. What are your thoughts about learning another language?

entry.title: The New, New Dominican in January 2011 - Part 1
entry.summary:
There some basic reasons why I go back to the Dominican time and time again. Some of that is easy to describe (great weather, good-looking people, beautiful scenery) - but it's the stuff that is increasingly harder to describe that I'd like to take a look at in this first of many part look at the Dominican in 2011. I have written quite a bit about the Dominican here, and I hope you join me in revisiting a locale that is near-and dear to my heart.

This time around I was able to see more of this great country than I have ever seen. I started in Punta Cana at a resort called the Majestic Elegance and then was able to get to the "north coast" by bus. This would be a north-west bound trip through Santo Domingo and around the famed mountains of the north. On display during this trip was the wonderful and scenic countryside that is often missed by those that choose to say resort-bound. The small villages, the great people, the makeshift stands offering various wares and the sugar cane fields (that kind of reminded me of looking at corn). The beauty of all this is breathtaking, and one I imagine the Dominican's take for granted.

But, the beauty is still not that "thing" that draws me to this place. It's enough, I'm sure, to draw anyone else what has had the opportunity to be out here - but It's not what I'm trying to describe. And, as you might imagine I met a number of folks, both inside and outside of the resorts I was in. One such fellow was a very helpful cab driver named Saidoo (I may have the spelling wrong there). His English was great and very helpful as I enlisted in his help to get me (and my mobile phone) connected to a local provider. My first interaction with him required that he take me to a mall, then back to the resort (to get my passport) and then to return again. The rides were a little pricey, but they wet down in price as my necessity went up. I appreciated that. He was incredibly helpful in getting me to the right bus for the start of my journey and ended up being the man that could get anything I needed. Saidoo was also very well versed in the bigger picture Dominican - he was a pleasure to speak with.

Still though, the helpfulness of everyday Dominicans is not that "thing" I'm looking to get across. Something here is just so amazing. While in Puerto Plata, a conversation with my good friend Davi lead to a startling piece of information. The local "iglesia" or church in the Barrio had not been paying it's bills. It was past -due on rent for a staggering 9 months. The big question in my mind was - how the hell would this place still be here after this long? Davi turns to me, smiles, and says "They are too well-respected". I really didn't think I could imagine a Canada or anywhere else with rules like these. Rules that could be so easily broken because of the enormous respect you may have in the community. Indeed, I have always known this was a place that favored "Working things out naturally" as opposed to what is all to common in Canada "legislatively working things out".

Oh, and things get worked out roughly in many places too - it's not always pretty, but the system seems to work and defy what we commonly accept as Canadians. But, that still wasn't it. While still in the Barrio, I met Giancarlo, the son of my good friend Martin. It was great that he had noticed me from previous trips - though he spoke no English and, frankly, my Spanish sucks. He seemed excited to show me his new bicycle. I went around the corner to check it out and, wow, it was in rough shape. The chain was rusted and bent in unusual ways, the center shaft (for the pedals) was loose, jammed and made riding impossible, and the bike had a flat on the back. Yet, still, Giancarlo was excited and clearly wanted to see if I could help fix it.

I went over and did what I could - the chain was a challenge, but I took my time to unravel it and get it onto the gears. Good, that was a start. I asked Giancarlo to go after some tools and he came back with a huge adjustable wrench - good enough - I can work with this. I loosened the center nut and found a huge piece (possibly bearings) was missing. Not good. I had another idea, why not tighten it as much as possible? I did that and managed to improve the ride-ability of the bike. I then gave it to Giancarlo and he looked as if I had given him Christmas present. He went straight to the "tire guy" to get the back tube fixed and he was riding that bike for the entire week (and getting flats) while I was here.

This is the lesson, and that "thing" that is so hard to describe. I could call it a certain positivity or appreciation for the things and friends you have - but it's more. It's this outlook that Dominicans have that is often described with a "Tranquillo", but to me is the essence of what brings me back. Problems really do roll of their shoulders. They appreciate the little things more and let go what they don't seem to get. They work hard, as a group of people, more than any other people I have ever met. We have so much to learn from other places, and I would start by teaching Canada to live a little (or allot) more Dominican.

entry.title: 10 Best Movies of 2010
entry.summary:
Here's the thing, I tend to watch a lot of movies. It may be because, instead of watching TV, I end up watching movies? I'm really not sure why I have always liked watching movies - and even seeing what it takes to makes movies. It's all entertainment and escape at it's best. Each year, I can say I've seen most of what's out there, though some movies (often Oscar Bait-y types) escape my viewing pleasure.

This year, there were a number of great and cool movies that I thought were the best. Some that probably deserve mention, but I haven't seen are Black Swan, True Grit, Enter The Void, The Kids are All Right, King's Speech, and Winter's Bone. For the rest, take a look at what I thought were the best of this year.

[![image][1]][1]

10. Get Him To The Greek (IMDB, Amazon)
The best comedy this year has to be Russell Brand's return as rock star Aldous Snow. It almost seems like he was meant to play this character. Previusly, Brand played this character in another wonderful comedy, Forgetting Sarah Marshall. I really loved the chemistry between Brand and Jonah Hill and the cameos alone were funny as hell. P. Diddy was great here too, who knew he could be funny?. It's mostly stupid and gross comedy, but there is a serious side there too. This is precisely the way I would envision the process of picking up a drugged out rock star.

[![image][3]][3]

9. The Karate Kid (IMDB, Amazon)
I was really not expecting to like this. The little I knew about it (Kung Fu as the fighting style not Karate, relative unknown Jaden Smith, Jackie Chan) - made me think this really was going to be trash. Boy, was I surprised with what I saw! Smith did a great job of acting like a kid with a lot to learn, Jackie Chan wasn't doing his regular jokey shtick here either. The understated nature of nearly everything in this movie makes it come out as a real winner - and wipes thoughts of original out of your mind. The fact that it made a crap load of money probably guarantees a sequel.

[![image][7]][7]

8. Machete (IMDB, Amazon)
I love so much about this film that it's a wonder why it's not higher on my list. Machete is the movie trailer that turned into an actual movie. And that movie is amazing in ways that are unexplainable. Watching Trejo finally getting a leading role and letting him rip shit up like he does. Michelle Rodriguez looks incredible and plays a great hard-ass. If you are a fan of the grind house style movie, this is your movie. And, even thought it didn't make a lot of money it mademoney. I hope to see more of this.

[![image][11]][11]

7. Let Me In (IMDB, Amazon)
Let Me In was another of those surprise movies. When I heard that they were remaking the AMAZING Swedish movie Let the Right One In, I was more than a bit cynical. This seemed too soon for this. What ended up on screen was incredible for a movie that so many were not looking forward too. Most of this rested on the shoulders of Chloe Moretz and I should she did a great job of being strong and venerable all at the same time. Richard Jenkins was great as the father. Do yourself a favor and see both Let the Right One In and this movie.

[![image][15]][15]

6. Buried (IMDB, Amazon)
This movie is a testament to how much can be done with so little. Essentially this is one man, a phone, dirt and a coffin. What Ryan Reynolds does here is make me believe that he's in trouble and imminent danger. The tension in the movie exists right to the last minute with what I'll describe as an unexpected ended. I wasn't expect it, at least. Rodrigo Cortés makes a wonderful, basic and thrilling story, work. As an added bonus, most of the released posers were incredible leading up to the film. This is one that I was looking forward to when I heard about it.

[![image][19]][19]

5. The Social Network (IMDB, Amazon)
Another surprise movie, but it really shouldn't have been a surprise. Look at the talent behind this - director David Fincher and writer Aaron Sorkin. What they made with this movie was more than the technical details (which is often wrong in movies to begin with). They made a movie about the beginnings of an idea - and made that movie at exactly a time when Facebook was in the news. You have great performances by Eisenberg and Timberlake and genuinely interesting characters.

[![image][23]][23]

4. Scott Pilgrim vs The World (IMDB, Amazon)
The movie that practically every geek on the planet was waiting for, finally arrived in 2010. And it was very good. For a movie about a guy from Toronto, shot in Toronto this was a source of great pride to see our wonderful city on display like this. Casa Loma never looked so good! Well, it had me at Toronto. But, so much of everything else about this movie is amazing. From the hyperactive action, to the performances by Cera and Winstead to the sets to, well, everything else. A great movie.

[![image][27]][27]

3. Kick-Ass (IMDB, Amazon)
2010 was definitely the year for Toronto as a location. In this movie, Toronto was the location - but the in-movie city remained unknown. Kick-Ass, of course, was the introduction to super heroes without any super powers. A new kind of comic book movie. And, wow, does it Kick Ass. All of the characters were interesting and flawed and the humor of it all made me laugh a lot. Also Hit Girl is someone you never want to meet in a dark alley.

[![image][31]][31]

2. The Town (IMDB, Amazon)
The one thing you'll be struck by with this second amazing directorial effort by Ben Affleck, is the weight of emotion in all of the characters here. Everyone in this movie is just excellent, from Ben Affleck to Rebecca Hall to Jon Hamm to Jeremy Renner. This is a very character driven movie about a small town in Boston and, frankly, the story just blows you away. Not by how original the story is, but by HOW it's told. I expect Affleck to get an Oscar or three for this one.

[![image][35]][35]

1. Inception (IMDB, Amazon)
Christopher Nolan is a movie-making genius. What he does with story, sound and image is just incredible. Inception is on the top of most people's lists this year because it is one thing - the best movie of 2010. The story is so multi-layered, so interesting, so visual - you'll go back many times and still not fully understand what this all means. A beautiful film in every regard. You'll also love how Nolan has made an effort to use as much real and practical effects as possible - it shows in the final product. I can't wait to see what he does next.

Movies I thought really sucked this year:

Shutter Island (IMDB, Amazon)
This one is moody and well-made and incredibly actied by DiCaprio - but I felt the story was stupid. Really, I saw was was coming a mile away and there was really no suspense to it. You can make garbage look pretty, but it's still garbage right?

The Human Centipede (IMDB, Amazon)
Really, what were they thinking? That's pretty much what was going through my mind every minute of this film. I essentially felt like the woman at the back of the line on this one. Force fed fecal matter of a movie. Brutal.

The Book of Eli (IMDB, Amazon)
The book is a bible. Eli is blind. Really horrible movie.

.. and probably many more that I can't think of. Better to bring in the new year with positivity! Tell me what your favorite move(s) were this year? Ho close is my list to your's? Did I miss anything?

entry.title: Personal Project: Re-Finishing a Side Table
entry.summary:
[![image][]][]

As you probably know, I'm a sucker for a new project or something cheap and cool. This time around I needed to find an end table to sit on the left of the couch in the living room. I was thinking this may hold a lamp or perhaps just hold magazines or a nice looking chess set. You may not know this, but Side Tables are damn expensive too. looking at these things I was thinking (1) I don't want to pay a lot for the table and (2) I want it to match the American Walnut stain of other tables in the house - mainly because I suck at matching colors. With that, I went out not specifically looking for a table, but keeping this in mind if I came across it. And, boy, did I get what I was looking for!

[![image][1]][1]

On one fine October day I happened upon the Courtice Flea Market in a small town just to the east of Oshawa. I had never been here previously, but if I were to try and prepare you for this place - I would say it's one big junk pile (I say that as affectionately as I possibly can). I wasn't actually here to look for a table specifically - but I was walking through an area with some interesting furniture piled up and came across a small sturdy looking side table. The table certainly didn't inspire much interest when I first saw it. The table had lots of scratches and paint cracks. But, looking at it from afar, it was the size I was looking for. I decided to get a closer look.

The table when I brought it home

As you see in the above picture, those cracks and scratches were quite plentiful. When I actually went up to the table and picked it up - that's when I decided I wanted it. The weight of the table was quite nice, and, I'm not a person who is able to determined the type of wood by picking it up - but this wood really looked like something I could work with. I decided to talk to the lady about buying the table. Sticker Price: $15 - Price Paid: $10.

The various parts of the table

I was pretty excited when I brought the table back - so much so that I started to work on it right away.

#1 - Sand with 90 Grit sandpaper
After taking the table apart I used an orbital sander with 90 grit sandpaper to get the old stain and finishing off the table. After the first day, the table looked like this:

After the first sanding, I wasn't completely finished

There was something unusual I found after the first day, the wood used on the top level of the table seemed to be different from the wood used on the middle level. Also, it appeared as though the legs were using the same wood as the middle level. The wood on the table top was more of a thin wood covering with possible particle board underneath - not good - I was going to have to take care while sanding this level.

#2 - Sand with 120 grit sandpaper
So, I was being rather touchy with the wood, but I managed to get the first step done without any major damage. Also, learning from the last time I took on a table, I was very careful not to place any of the sanded wood into or around water. This second stage of sanding went quite smooth and quickly. The wood responded nicely to the 120 grit paper as well. Also, I find that I tend to use half as much of the higher grit sandpaper as I do of the lower grit.

Sanding is finished

#3 - Stain the wood

[![image][6]][]

With the wood sanded the way I wanted - I moved on to the staining stage. In this case I decided to use a staining pad for all of this process - including the legs. Given the small surface area that needed stain, I wasn't going to need much for this at all. The stain I used (shown at right) was Varathane, with the "American Walnut" color. I made it a point to keep all of the tables I've stained so far at the same color. I was fond of American Walnut when I first saw it on wood, so I stayed with it. You'll also notice that the can of stain is small - this $8.50 can of stain has so far been enough for me to stain a dining room table, a coffee table and now a side table. Remarkable how much this stain can cover. The key to staining woos seems to be the ability to cover the surface in as uniform a way as you can possibly do. The rest, will be dictated by how well you have sanded and the kind of wood you have. I feel the better the wood, the better absorbed the stain is. This is generally the most important stage of the process.

The wood after just being stained. Notice how dull the surface is.

#4 - Adding the Finish
With this step, I also used a Varathane product for the finishing. For all of my tables, I preferred to use a glossy finish, but you may decide that gloss is a little too shiny. I have been pleased with the Varathane product, so I'll keep using it. For this table, I decided early on that three coats was going to be enough - if the table looked like it was going to need more, I would add more. It turns out three coats was more than enough. It's a good plan to (if you're not sure) stat with three coats and add as you need too. In between coats you want to use a pad on the wood surface to pop any bubbles and generally let the wood dry for at leas 6-10 hours. The longest I left the wood before another coat was a day.

After the first coat of stain

#5 - The final product
The the stain done, and the table dry enough, I put it together. you are really going to want to leave a good long time (maybe a week?) for the finish to harden before actually using the wood. So, here are before and after shots of the table's ultimate location:

Before adding the table

After adding the table

That's it! Any thoughts? I hope this series of blogs might have also given you some ideas about changing up some stuff you have around the house. As always, thoughts and questions are more than welcome!

entry.title: Thoughts on Negativity
entry.summary:
[![image][]][image]

Recently, I read a nice little article on Pick The Brain about the idea that negativity can be a motivation killer. And another article entitled Why Optimists Prosper. I find myself in negative situations all the time. My work can be a cauldron of negativity. Most of what I generally do is about fixing problems - that's not a situation that breeds allot of positivity. I too, succumb to negative thought processes, and when I do, I usually pay for it. I usually snap out of it, but the challenge has always been to be motivated from a positive place towards a better future. I have been self employed now for more than 10 years, a testament to a sort of positive motivation. I have come across too many folks that, for some reason, are inherently negative and I always hope to see that change for the better.


I'll give you an example, you must know folks like this. Your supposed to meet your friend/lover/sibling/parent at a later time during the day, but your still working. So tied up, in fact, that you can't get to the phone as early as you would like. The day wears on and you finally get the chance to call and you say that you have to work late and you can't make it for your date/dinner/meeting/function. What's more, you say you don't know when you'll be done. Well, the more positive of you would probably say to themselves "OK, he/she's working late, no big deal. I don't know the whole picture, but I'll find out more when he/she returns". The negative thinker will instantly be thinking: "He's going to be late, he's (done something wrong /cheating / hurt himself/ fallen off a cliff / hit a moose)" and then that person would automatically start to feel anxious, or in some cases cry or act out in horrible or angry ways.

This tends to be deeper than just flipping out over late appointments, it's an instant and internal leaning towards the "worst in people" instead of a positive thoughts. In our daily lives there are all sorts of things that happen that are positive and negative. You might be driving along and another driver cuts you off, you flip him the "bird" and keep driving. Surely, that is a negative thing, but that is not what I speak of when I talk about negativity. You may be in a conversation and the person your talking to pisses you off, and in turn you go off on them and give them a piece of your mind. That's also negative, but not what I refer to here. These are all expressions of anger and annoyance, a human emotion. Often anger can be used as a tool to motivate others (or just as a release for us). Anger is a tool, it comes, goes and it passes.

The negativity I speak of is sort of an internal trigger for people. It's the sort of thing that keeps us from starting a businesses because of fear, laziness or or lack of confidence. It's the sort of thing that makes people use humor as a weapon to keep us from seeing their true sadness (and perhaps them too). This may also what makes so many act out in selfish or adversarial ways. The instantly negative thinker will assume everyone is trying to take something from them. I think, in many ways, this kind of thing is the underpinnings of what we might know as depression - but I don't say I understand that. Actually, I don't understand anything about the psychology of this, but, what I do understand is the loss that comes from loosing loved ones that have succumbed to this.

Being overtaken by negativity holds us back in so many ways. It keeps us from taking the time to understand other's points of view. It keeps us from looking at or exploring the more important larger picture and gaining a much-needed understanding. It keeps us from appreciating the many wonderful things life has given us, often hiding under the surface. When those that are in the throes negativity need to be motivated, it does not seem to be possible from within. Struggling towards a common goal is not possible because the struggle is stifling to them. I have met a great many greatly motivated, intelligent, and beautiful people who are held hostage by their own negativity. In many ways it cripples them all that know them.

So, why do so many get trapped in this negative mental process? What can be done to stem the tide of negativity? What if you're doing the things I describe here?

I know this doesn't happen overnight, but being surrounded by those that will support you is important. Being good to those that try to be there for you - this is hard sometimes - but good things breed more good things. I feel that, sometimes, forcing yourself to be patient also helps. Even if the outcome or answers don't exist- just stopand let it happen. Let it sink in until you have more details and you might simply free yourself from the negative shackles by waiting. Try to separate yourself from those that bring negativity in your life. Also, do this with negative influences like gossip or the news, if you can.

What do you think? Am I way off the mark here? Is there a better word to describe this than negativity?

entry.title: Book Review: Under the Dome
entry.summary:
From Wikipedia

As a techie, I am rarely presented the opportunity to read fiction books. Yes, most of my reading tends to be news, current events and articles or books related to the (sometimes dry) computer industry. When I saw Stephen Kings UNDER THE DOME in hardcover hanging on the shelf of my local Chapters, I was more than intrigued.

UNDER THE DOME follows a number of townsfolk living in Chester's Mill, Maine (King has a thing for Maine in his books). These seemingly normal people are transformed in crazy and interesting ways as a domed force field of some kind caps the small town completely. No one comes in, no one leaves.

This trapping of the towns people "like ants" is a perfect scenario for King. His beautifully descriptive writing tells stories within even the mundane of facts. He really gets into the "why" of what people do more than any other fiction author I have read (admittedly, not many). Those little tangents about what people are thinking at moments before or after things happen are classic King moves.

More than the descriptions too, the characters are very strong. The good guy named Dale Barbara is a strong fellow I imagine as big, rough looking. But with humility. The bad guy - Jim Rennie - is somewhat the same, but with the look of perfect evil. I can already see who will play these guys in a movie. I pick Ron Perlman for Barbara and Deniro for Rennie. Perfect. I can't quite place Junior, but I would have bet that someone like Heath Ledger could make that part great.

The stakes are high too. You might not think so, but the kind of crazy shit that can go down in a small town is really endless. When that movie is made, it will need some really cool special effects. Also, I expect this to be 'Hard R' - any less would be a disservice to the amazingly described gore and horrible acts in the story.

The gore is not all - I'm fascinated by the technology surrounding the dome. I wont give away too much about what (or who) creates the dome; but the tech behind the 15 minute pulses, the small holes in the exterior of the dome and the level of transparency. King doesn't delve into this nearly as much as I would liked. I wanted to know more.

I won't give you any more about the story either - you have to read the close to 1100 pages yourself. I think if you take the ride, you'll be happy you did.

Just a note: it took me seven damn months to read this book. Seven months! You can grab the book here from Amazon.ca: Under the Dome

entry.title: Personal Project: Coffee Table - Sanding, Staining, Varnishing
entry.summary:
[![image][]][image]

Over the recent months I have taken on a number of projects to improve the look this house. In this case, I found a small wooden coffee table at a Value Village for $19.99 and I saw potential in it. I could visualize the look of it finished, even as it sit in the furniture section of Value Village. The table as I bought it was not stained at all - it had a number of large gashes on the top of it and the varnish had a somewhat off-color to it. The great thing about this table (besides the price) was how sturdy it appeared to be built. Nothing screams "project" like some basic solid wood. I'm going to show you how to take a coffee table, stain it and make it look great. This can be done for easily less than $30 ($70, if you can't borrow a sander).

[][] Coffee Table: The original look of the table

Sanding is usually the most important part of the project. You want to make sure you get the previous varnish off the wood and yet don't want to take too much of the wood with it. To start with, I used an orbital sander with the (Velcro sanding sheets). These are generally about $40 at a hardware store. I started with 60 grit sandpaper. As I was sanding I decided I wanted to stain as much of the table as possible - so I took it apart into pieces. The roof of my truck was quite useful for doing some of this work from waist-level. Here's a look a piece of the table and the sander I was using:

[![image][2]][]

After sanding everything with the 60 grit sandpaper, I moved on to the 120 grit sandpaper to smooth out the rough surfaces. Usually just two passes of sandpaper is enough, even though some will tell you that you need to do a third (possibly with 180 grit). With this finished, I was happy with the sanding stage.

Sanding Tip: Sand in the direction of the grain of the wood. Also, I was doing all this outside of my garage to keep from getting dust all over - when sanding, be sure to wear a mask!

[][] The small bottle of stain used

After the sanding was finished, I started to stain. I used Varathane Professional Premium Wood Stain - American Walnut (236ml) - for this job. As you can see by the size of the can, very little stain is required. This can was half-empty when I started and still has some stain left - you will not use much of this stuff. I used a natural paintbrush and simply started to stain (continuing to stay with the grain).

Staining Tip: It's sloppy and tends to really show later if you make mistakes. I only placed one coat of the stain on the wood - but after the first coat I took the time to touch up some of the spots that I missed on the wood. be consistent and even whenever possible.

After letting the stain dry for a week ( yea, I gave it extra time), I came back to start the lacquer stage. The varnish is used to protect the wood and stain and create the finish of the table. For this process I used and for this I used Varathane - Professional Clear Finish (Oil Int. Clear Gloss) (946ml). The gloss is great for table tops because it really gives it that bit of shine you notice in a room. For this project I will put three coats on the wood letting it dry about 6 hours in-between coats. You'll use quite a bit more of the varnish than you will the stain, so you want to pickup a larger can - I used the 946ml size (roughly a liter).

[][] The varnish used - note the "Clear Gloss" - this is shiny

Varnishing Tips: (a) give the previous coat time to dry, I gave it at least 6 hours. I didn't put new varnish on if the surface was still tacky (b) making sure you paint it all on evenly. This is a challenge with glossy varnish since it hard to tell where you last painted and (c) making sure that you do a light sanding or use a scrub pad on the previous coating of varnish . This takes away the air bubbles and makes the next coat smoother. In my case three coats was enough.

One warning, during all of this, water is your enemy. You have to use varsol to clean the brushes (not water). You have to make sure the raw wood does NOT come in contact with water or it will stain. I accidentally rested one of the legs in water (just after sanding) and here's what that did to the leg. Notice how prominent the stain is:

[![image][5]][]

Now, the project is finished, the varnish on the table has hardened and I have to say - I'm very happy with it. This is a definite improvement over my previous table sanding project. I think I'm learning more every time I take on one of these. Here are a few more pictures of the final, stained table. Click through for larger versions.

[![image][6]][]
[![image][7]][]
[![image][8]][]

I'd love to hear more about your own projects. What did you think of this? Do you have any staining tips of your own to share?

entry.title: Why I've always been a fan of Magnum P.I.
entry.summary:
[![image][]][]

This is one of a very few personal posts you'll see me write here. The regular fare on this blog is usually a mix of computer, technical stuff with the occasional outrage over something with a dash of vacation stories added. After spending a little time over the last few days (re) watching the 8th (and final) season of Magnum PI, I thought I would stop and reflect on what that show has meant to me over the years. It's almost corny now that I'm 36 years old that I would have identified with a television character so much.


To understand this, you really have to have a sense of timeline. Magnum PI was in it's first run on TV from 1981 to 1988, this would have placed the show on CBS in the rage of years for me from when I was 8 years old to just about the middle of my 14th year. I was a kid in every sense of the word when this show was running. Magnum PI was also a very popular show - one of the higher rated shows for it's time. If they wanted too, the producers of the show could have kept it going for some time after it ended. But, in the spring of 1988, the show ended.

[![image][1]][]

I know what you're thinking, and your wrong. This show turned out to be more than a show for me in a number of ways that go beyond some pipsqueak kid watching the boob-tube. This is the unusual story behind this show and it's effect on me when I was so young and it's apparent effect on me now. As it turns out I'm in the middle of the years that the Thomas Magnum character played out on the show (33 to 41). In many ways its interesting, and sometimes scary to see this show with fresh eyes as an older and (somewhat) wiser person - seeing things that the kid could never have seen. I've also only seen the last season, none of the 7 seasons that preceded it.

There are so many coincidences that have happened in my life that have linked me to the Magnum PI character. perhaps as a child, I just needed a character to identifiably with - something akin to GI Joe for a generation before me. But, there always seemed to be more.

In 1984, as an 11 year old, my father decided to take me and my sister to a baseball game. Since we lived in Sarnia at the time, it would ave been difficult or impossible to get to Toronto to see a Blue Jays game. We, instead ended up going to Detroit to catch a game at the Tiger Stadium, watching a team that was on a serious tear that year and one that would go on to win the World Series. This essentially became my favorite baseball team as I followed the Tigers more and more as I got older. I don't recall seeing the Magnum PI show at the time, but to see that he was a big Tigers fan was really cool!

There was the season when I finally started to watch Magnum PI in first-run episodes. This being the last season, I was surprised to find that in the final episode - they would use allot of Otis Redding's music. I had heard allot of music from Otis Redding after seeing some John Hughes movies years before and had become a huge fan of soul music, and Otis Redding. I remember in the mid-80's, working in downtown Toronto and after hearing Otis Redding for the first time - I wanted that music! I remember walking up and down Young St searching through all those classic record stores just to find any of his stuff. To hear that music in the final episodes was an amazing coincidence, and kept me watching.

[![image][2]][2]

There were other things, that naturally as a kid, I would end up emulating at the time. I remember walking around with a Detroit Tigers baseball hat quite a bit - but I also remember at the time thinking "am I wearing this because I'm a fan of the Tigers or because I'm a fan of Magnum PI?". I guess it wasn't much of a big deal, but in the mind of a young boy with no identity to speak of, it mattered to me. Seeing stuf like the logo on Magnum's shirt as he would kayak - it was of a man's head and the number of 14. Naturally I would find this interesting because my own birthday was June 14th.

Much of my younger years were a bit crazy, and having an escape like Magnum PI actually helped me enormously. I found myself enjoying the friendships between all of the main characters - Magnum, Rick , T.C., Higgins and the two dogs, Zeus and Apollo. The chemistry between all of the actors was amazing - something we rarely see in today's polished CSI'esque shows. As I would start watching the show more, I would see allot of the re-runs as they were aired in syndication - but I never managed to get to see the real narrative of the show as it was released. In fact, not only have I not seen all of the 162 Magnum PI episodes, I haven't really sen many of them in sequence either.

And I get some of the in-jokes of the show (if you want to call them jokes). I know that, for example, the number of 162 episodes was not a random number - it's actually the number of games in a Major League Baseball season. When I watch the show more these days, there are others that I see too. It's amazing what you see, even after the years have passed.

[![image][3]][]

Now that the show is entirely out on DVD (Seasons 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8) I suggest you go check them out, or at the very least buy me one of them. I have always wondered how many other Magnum PI fans there are out there besides myself. I did once come across a customer how had a model of the same Ferrari that was used in the series too. Behind the model was a picture of him sitting in a Ferrari in a setting that looked like Hawaii.

This is the next step for me as a fan of the show. I would like to finally get up and go check out the location where all of this was filmed. I want to finally make the pilgrimage to all the various locations to check out what it's like down there. After all of these years, I have no doubt that everyone there has forgotten about this 80's TV show, but I certainly haven't forgotten. I look forward to digging up more episodes and checking them out. If you're a fan too, I'd love to hear about why you are!

entry.title: Speeding in Toronto? Be careful, watch out for ignorance!
entry.summary:
Yes, it's those unrealistic cops and other ignorant folks you need to worry about in Toronto and outskirts. Today, I had a basic exchange with one such member of the police about speeding on Twitter. The officer, Tim Burrows, who Tweets as @trafficservices had the following exchange with me:

[![image][]][]

Now, I need to qualify all of this. Car crashes are dangerous no matter how fast you go. I have been in a number of them myself as a driver, passenger and a pedestrian. Always be safe when driving and *always* drive according to your better judgement (the may not always be what's posted on a sign).

Here's the thing, we should all be ashamed of the system we drive in. The process of catching speeders and other traffic rule breakers is clearly nothing more than a cash grab, or possibly a tax on us. Let's be clear, traffic collisions can be scary and dangerous, but most of the rules we have to follow on the road have nothing to do with safety.

His basic points were three things (1) speed traps are in plain sight (2) speeding tickets are revenue neutral and (3) rules are all about safety. Let's look at these ideas, because you should at least be more informed than the officer on what we face on a daily basis. Don't drink his Kool Aid.

Let's look at this, point by point.

1. Speed Traps are in "plain sight" - There are a number of examples of this being just plain false. The cops in Toronto don't want you to see them as you approach because you'll slow down, so they resort to a number of tactics to hide themselves. As a deterrent to speeding, this is useless, because if no one sees the cop, they are reminded of nothing, much less that they should slow down. Here are a number of examples:

[![image][1]][1]

Found on a blog named Spacing Toronto, the picture is small, but you can clearly see that the Police have done what they can to hide themselves behind the trees. If not for the speeder they stopped, you would not have seen these guys on approach. Another spot I'm very familiar with is the corner of Gerrard St E and Blackburn St. This is a common hidden location for the police to hide and catch those coming off the bridge covering the Don Valley Parkway. It looks like this (source: Google Maps):

[![image][2]][]

You can probably tell what they hide behind in the summer months, yes, the trees, the sloping pavement and the fence all create this perfect way of tricking people into thinking nothing is there. Another common trick I have seen used is the lone cop standing on a bridge pointing his speed gun down on the highway below. Once they catch someone, they call ahead and get a cruiser to stop you. Plain Sight? If you are lucky enough to catch the cops in the act of hiding a speed trap, I would love to see the pictures. We have to prove this major fallacy wrong.

2. Speed Traps/Tickets are Revenue Neutral after all costs factored - this is one big example of a fuzzy accounting process. The process where they count up all the costs to ONLY the parties you deem important and then leave all the rest out. The costs to those drivers who are fined at these incredibly high rates are not revenue neutral at all. To most, the high cost of the ticket is just the beginning. There is the social stigma attached to being a speeder (more on that later), the high cost of taking time off work and/or hiring legal representation, and the insanely high cost of the insurance if you were to be convicted of one of these charges. In some cases it gets even worse, you may in some situations have your license suspended (without notification) and/or face demerit points. Add all this up, and you have an incredible loss of the little spending money a person takes home after tax - even for the most minor of speeding charges!

Look at the number of paralegal companies that exist in Toronto, my search on Google yielded 1,333 results! The hide-and-catch speeders game not only pads the pocketbooks of the Police, it has created an entire market for legal services. Not to mention that many of these paralegal companies prey on the more uninformed folks who are clearly intimidated by the cumbersome legal system we have. That's a post for another day.

3. It's all about safety - This is one of the biggest lies that the cops will ever feed you. They are not hiding behind the trees with radar guns to keep us safe (revenue generation). They are not trying to create the "speeding is criminal" stigma to create a safer road environment (public support, fear). They don't over-legislate rules like the "racing law" that get's your license suspended, gets you fined up to $10,000 and your car towed immediately - because they want safer roads (all of the above). None of the current speed enforcement policies or budget goes to safety.

What, then, would the Police and Government be doing about all of the above if they were actually trying to curb collisions and keep us safer? I'm glad you asked, that is the most important question here. We need to collectively stop these jokers from screwing us over. I personally don't trust them with tax money as they stay "revenue neutral". Here's what we need to go in the right direction:

Roundabouts- Many studies have concluded that roundabouts on our roads reduce collisions. A Washington-based study concluded the following about roundabouts:

  • more than 90% reduction in fatalities
  • 80% reduction in injuries
  • 40% reduction in total number of crashes

Source: "Safety Effect of Roundabout Conversions in the United States: Empirical Bayes Observational Before-After Study." Transportation Research Record No. 1751, [Transportation Research Board (TRB)][], National Academy of Sciences (NAS), Washington, D.C. 2001

Even an article in The Economist (subscription required). talks about the benefits of roundabouts. Provinces like Alberta are starting to install them - here's what one looks like. But here in Toronto, little or nothing but talk. And, how many roundabouts do we have in Toronto? I'm sure you can count the number with your fingers. How much of that "revenue" could be spent on roundabouts for safety instead of more radar or laser guns?

Speed Limits - Did you know that the 401's speed limit was actually 112km/hour in 1976 before it was dropped to the current 100/km an hour (source). Did you also know that the minimum design speed of the 401 is apparently 130km/hour? Speed Limits need to be adjusted to be appropriate to the area they are in. In the case of the above Gerrard St E speed trap, the road itself is usually heavy up to River St. when you arrive at the DVP Overpass, and then the road opens up. Those drivers who enjoy this brief relief of traffic and go faster than the posted 40km/hr speed, are however, clipped immediately by the cash hungry cops. The speed limits on the roads need to reflect real world conditions, and not just set (and used) by the police for their advantage. Many other locations probably deserve lower speed limits, but the majority of the roads in Toronto have speed limits set WAY too low.

The key statistic about speed, though is really not that "high speed kills" as they would have you believe. It is actually the deviation from the normal speed you are travelling on. Yes, that means Grama driving at 40+km/hr lower than others on the 401 will be MORE of a risk than someone driving 40+km over the normal speed. Here's a graph to illustrate that (source) :

[![image][4]][4]

The speed "stigma" and this the push to make those that might speed look like criminals - needs to stop. The cops need to stop wasting our money on hiding in bushes trying to catch speeders and put that money in more useful endeavors (like building roundabouts, catching actual bad guys, perhaps?). Everyone needs to call or email their local politician and tell them that the current policies are unacceptable. When you hear a cop talk stupidness about speeding policies - correct them!

entry.title: Roger Ebert - Movie Critic, and wise man
entry.summary:
Today I was reading a fascinating Esquire article about none other than Roger Ebert - I had seen him on TV years ago when he was on Siskel and Ebert. More after the jump...

You might remember the how that show was - they review Pulp Fiction here (Ebert is the one on the right):

Roger, facing his own mortality, goes on to say this:

"I believe that if, at the end of it all, according to our abilities, we have done something to make others a little happier, and something to make ourselves a little happier, that is about the best we can do. To make others less happy is a crime. To make ourselves unhappy is where all crime starts. We must try to contribute joy to the world. That is true no matter what our problems, our health, our circumstances. We must try. I didn't always know this, and am happy I lived long enough to find it out."

Wow, thank you Roger for the wise words.

entry.title: White Cowbell - Horseshoe Tavern - March 8, 2008
entry.summary:
My lord, it just so happens we push an all-time snowfall record on the day the Cowbell come home. I was not going to let a little thing like snow get in my way! I did not get to see last night's show in Hamilton - and I missed all of the western tour.. So I was more than a little bummed...

I get there after two hours of driving, already everyone but my sister had dropped out of the night's proceedings, and to make matters worse - I have to wait in some sort of lineup? I thought "What is this? Do they not know who I am?". Well, they didn't, and I waited about 30mins to get in, the lads had already finished the opening and a song.. I was so glad to be back inside the Casa Cowbell for the first time this year!

This was a packed house! The fans were pumped! it also appeared to be a ticket with 7 other bands (as one of the very friendly bouncers would explain). I was so much more in tune with things here than the last time. The Jager girls were occasionally circulating around the stage refreshing the front-row devotees, I was stuck a few rows back double-fisting a couple Stella's...

Bubba would do an uncharacteristically perfect rendition of "Tear You a New One" - practice! The dancing girl looked great, she's lost weight, but Sgt Rock seems to have gained facial hair - that makes them even? You tell me. "Put The South In Your Mouth" gets interactive and then the boys are whisked off... Seriously, I must have gotten whiplash with how fast they spit!

I did get to say hi at various moment, I had to let Charles and the others know I had attended and then I was off myself. The very friendly and drunk lady I met at the stage was all too happy to share the she'd be married in a few days. Congratulations to you!!

It was a short one, yes - but it was sweet to see the WCO again and I look forward to this year's adventures!! What's next?

entry.title: Panama Backpacker Style - 6
entry.summary:
[![image][]][]

Day 13 - Penonomé
Waking up this morning the distinct sound of partying outside was really cool. I was told that this Carnival goes four days - all day, all night - and doesn't stop. I decided to walk towards the sounds, I had to remember where I was.. No street signs here to help. Gathering some landmarks I work backwards with these:

  1. MUSEO HNOS ARIAS MADRID, turn left
  2. Corp. el sol, turn right

I get to see the local Internet cafe - where the access is slow and they charge .60c an hour, by far the cheapest access in town. The one thing that is super annoying though, is that they filtered suspect "Porn" sites. I would be in Facebook and click on a friend's profile and a filtering message comes up and KILLS the web browser and all the tabs I have open! Brutal to say the least. That is good enough amusement for a couple hours, I then grab lunch at Pio Pio, and head back towards all the action in town. What action indeed! On the main street in town there are about 8 tanker trucks lined up and down road - the sole purpose of these being to spray water on the people below dancing in the sun. It was great, I went in and got wet and sprayed myself, I even got the chance to hop on top of a tanker and spray the people below! Wow, that was amazing. So many happy people.

I ran into Tania and we went to the river where the Queen of the Carnival was due to arrive - I ended up very tired so I went back for an afternoon nap... I slept a hell of a lot too .. Waking up sometime around 8pm, Tania and I walked back into town to eat and get on the Internet.. The party was in full swing but I was not drinking tonight.. Tomorrow we have to travel to panama city and stay our last day at the voyager hostel.

Day 14 - Back to Panama City
Its 7:20am in Penonomé.. Everyone here stayed up all night - so everyone is sleeping while I'm thinking about breakfast! I leave the house and headed for a walk - I walk up to the local Pio Pio store and ordered two scambled egg combos (huevo revoulto) because I was so hungry. I took the sausages back for Max, the family dog, to eat, and he loved them. I then worked out the plans for travel with Tania - we would leave right away on the bus and get to the hostel around 5pm. When we got there we met up with some really cool Canadian/Dutch/Americans and headed back out for carnival.. This version of carnival was much different than Penonomé - this was Pamama City and it was massive!! People in this (possibly million strong) crowd were throwing confetti on each other (this was the small circle that is cut out of paper with a three-hole punch).. They were also spraying some sort of foam out of cans to.. I was constantly impressed by how nice and welcoming everyone was ... It was a great party and I ended up drunk and had to stubble home on this one..

Day 15 - Homeward Bound
Waking up after last nights craziness was cool - I did have to struggle with confetti all over my body though , that was a real pain in the ass! We checked out of the hostel, Tania went back to carnival for the day and I went looking for food - I found a nice little place where I got some amazing chicken fried rice ... For 2.95 I ended up with a plate that would feed 5 people!!! I got a doggy bag to eat the rest at the airport. I was looking forward to getting back home. My ride to the airport would leave in a couple hours - grabbed two boxes of that cheap wine for the road and headed back to the hostel. The flight home was incredibly scary but I made it back! What's Next?

entry.title: Panama Backpacker Style - 5
entry.summary:
[![image][]][]

Day 10 - Bye El Valle, hello Penonomé

Morning returns and we all have decidedly less pep. No doubt, the drinking had something to do with it. We all straggle up, Don gets milk and we refresh the coffee demon. Packing and bussing ensues as we would head out of El Valle and drop the guys off at the hotel's street in Farillion. Tania and I stay on the bus and continue to a larger town named Penonomé - the capital of the province of Coclé. This town is filled with shops, I even managed to grab a panama flag here - now I have picked up everything I need. There are all sorts of stores named "Peter", Casa Peter, Mr Peter, Bla Bla Peter. At one very unusual moment, I find Internet access while Tania tells me she's going to get fries at Mr Peter. When I finish and go find her, she's nowhere to be found! I take my time and walk up and down the street, I get fries of my own and after about an hour, I decide to head back to the hotel. I was wondering what the hell happened to her. It was a very interesting process trying to explain to the man at the counter in the hotel that I was in room 605 "Seesh, cero, sank-oo" and that I wanted to get into the room without a key. After much sign language, probably a little bit of dancing and poor Spanish, the man with the big ring of keys let me in. I left a note for her and headed out back down the street. It was getting dark so I was getting a bit worried. While walking back into town - Tania was coming out of a mall. She had gone to do her nails. All was fine at this point. We were off to Pio Pio to eat chicken.

Panama 11 - Penonomé
All in all a low-key day in Penonomé... Not much more than shopping and hanging out at the hotel, I managed to walk from one end of the town to the other - the workers were clearly getting a large stage ready for Carnaval.

Panama 12 - Penonomé and Sona
Today, the Carnaval starts... There looked to be no chance to get to Las Tablas so we made the decision we weren't going there. We found some Americans that were willing to let us crash in their "crash pad", twelve of them were in the room next to us. Then, Tania found something better! Professor Ortiz - a local teacher in Penonomé - was willing to rent a room in his house. Sweet. We headed over there and dropped our bags and headed to my MAIN point of interest in Panama - Sona (well known for the location of the key prison in the show Prison Break). The 200km bus ride would cost no more than three bucks, but take a good three hours each way, we needed to get on two different busses. Once in Sona it was clear that this small town had no clue what type of fame has been brought to them, or why. While asking a police officer to take a picture with me, the description of the TV show "Prison Break" elicited deep, blank stares. They would end up saying a forceful no to any sort of pictures. I ended up with a picture at a local bank that said Sona. We stopped at a local chicken place for amazing rotisserie and then jumped on the bus back to Penonomé ...

The bus to Santiago was cool, but the bus from there to Penonomé was horrible! It was impossible to see out the windows to tell where you were - or even to tell if you had gotten to Penonomé , or if you were actually there. Tania asked again and we finally made it to where we were going.

Right when we returned we connected with Kimmie an Jesus be checked out the Carnaval that was going on.. It wasn't busy yet, but the people were coming in to town in droves. I cut the night short because I wasn't feeling so good.. Back to Prof Ortiz house...
